trans-unit.source: How to use Service Bus relay (.NET) | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to use Service Bus relay (.NET) | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use the Azure Service Bus relay service to connect two applications hosted in different locations.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use the Azure Service Bus relay service to connect two applications hosted in different locations.

trans-unit.source: This article describes how to use the Service Bus relay service.
trans-unit.target: This article describes how to use the Service Bus relay service.

trans-unit.source: The samples are written in C# and use the Windows Communication Foundation (WCF) API with extensions contained in the Service Bus assembly that is part of the Microsoft Azure .NET SDK.
trans-unit.target: The samples are written in C# and use the Windows Communication Foundation (WCF) API with extensions contained in the Service Bus assembly that is part of the Microsoft Azure .NET SDK.

trans-unit.source: For more information about the Service Bus relay, see the <linkText>Next steps</linkText><title></title> section.
trans-unit.target: For more information about the Service Bus relay, see the <linkText>Next steps</linkText><title></title> section.

trans-unit.source: The Service Bus relay service enables you to build hybrid applications that run in both an Azure datacenter and your own on-premises enterprise environment.
trans-unit.target: The Service Bus relay service enables you to build hybrid applications that run in both an Azure datacenter and your own on-premises enterprise environment.

trans-unit.source: The Service Bus relay facilitates this by enabling you to securely expose Windows Communication Foundation (WCF) services that reside within a corporate enterprise network to the public cloud, without having to open a firewall connection, or require intrusive changes to a corporate network infrastructure.
trans-unit.target: The Service Bus relay facilitates this by enabling you to securely expose Windows Communication Foundation (WCF) services that reside within a corporate enterprise network to the public cloud, without having to open a firewall connection, or require intrusive changes to a corporate network infrastructure.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Relay Concepts</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Relay Concepts</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The Service Bus relay allows you to host WCF services within your existing enterprise environment.
trans-unit.target: The Service Bus relay allows you to host WCF services within your existing enterprise environment.

trans-unit.source: You can then delegate listening for incoming sessions and requests to these WCF services to the Service Bus service running within Azure.
trans-unit.target: You can then delegate listening for incoming sessions and requests to these WCF services to the Service Bus service running within Azure.

trans-unit.source: This enables you to expose these services to application code running in Azure, or to mobile workers or extranet partner environments.
trans-unit.target: This enables you to expose these services to application code running in Azure, or to mobile workers or extranet partner environments.

trans-unit.source: Service Bus allows you to securely control who can access these services at a fine-grained level.
trans-unit.target: Service Bus allows you to securely control who can access these services at a fine-grained level.

trans-unit.source: It provides a powerful and secure way to expose application functionality and data from your existing enterprise solutions and take advantage of it from the cloud.
trans-unit.target: It provides a powerful and secure way to expose application functionality and data from your existing enterprise solutions and take advantage of it from the cloud.

trans-unit.source: This how-to article demonstrates how to use the Service Bus relay to create a WCF web service, exposed using a TCP channel binding, that implements a secure conversation between two parties.
trans-unit.target: This how-to article demonstrates how to use the Service Bus relay to create a WCF web service, exposed using a TCP channel binding, that implements a secure conversation between two parties.

trans-unit.source: To begin using the Service Bus relay in Azure, you must first create a service namespace.
trans-unit.target: To begin using the Service Bus relay in Azure, you must first create a service namespace.

trans-unit.source: A namespace provides a scoping container for addressing Service Bus resources within your application.
trans-unit.target: A namespace provides a scoping container for addressing Service Bus resources within your application.

trans-unit.source: To create a service namespace:
trans-unit.target: To create a service namespace:

trans-unit.source: Log on to the <linkText>Azure portal</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Log on to the <linkText>Azure portal</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In the left navigation pane of the Azure portal, click Service Bus.
trans-unit.target: In the left navigation pane of the Azure portal, click Service Bus.

trans-unit.source: In the lower pane of the Azure portal, click Create.
trans-unit.target: In the lower pane of the Azure portal, click Create.

trans-unit.source: In the Add a new namespace dialog box, enter a namespace name.
trans-unit.target: In the Add a new namespace dialog box, enter a namespace name.

trans-unit.source: The system immediately checks to see if the name is available.
trans-unit.target: The system immediately checks to see if the name is available.

trans-unit.source: After making sure the namespace name is available, choose the country or region in which your namespace should be hosted (make sure you use the same country/region in which you are deploying your compute resources).
trans-unit.target: After making sure the namespace name is available, choose the country or region in which your namespace should be hosted (make sure you use the same country/region in which you are deploying your compute resources).

trans-unit.source: Pick the same region that you intend to choose for deploying your application.
trans-unit.target: Pick the same region that you intend to choose for deploying your application.

trans-unit.source: This will give you the best performance.
trans-unit.target: This will give you the best performance.

trans-unit.source: Leave the other fields in the dialog box with their default values (Messaging and Standard tier), then click the check mark.
trans-unit.target: Leave the other fields in the dialog box with their default values (Messaging and Standard tier), then click the check mark.

trans-unit.source: The system now creates your namespace and enables it.
trans-unit.target: The system now creates your namespace and enables it.

trans-unit.source: You might have to wait several minutes as the system provisions resources for your account.
trans-unit.target: You might have to wait several minutes as the system provisions resources for your account.

trans-unit.source: The namespace you created then appears in the Azure portal and takes a moment to activate.
trans-unit.target: The namespace you created then appears in the Azure portal and takes a moment to activate.

trans-unit.source: Wait until the status is Active before continuing.
trans-unit.target: Wait until the status is Active before continuing.

trans-unit.source: In order to perform management operations, such as creating a relay connection, on the new namespace, you must configure the Shared Access Signature (SAS) authorization rule for the namespace.
trans-unit.target: In order to perform management operations, such as creating a relay connection, on the new namespace, you must configure the Shared Access Signature (SAS) authorization rule for the namespace.

trans-unit.source: For more information about SAS, see <linkText>Shared Access Signature Authentication with Service Bus</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about SAS, see <linkText>Shared Access Signature Authentication with Service Bus</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In the left navigation pane, click the Service Bus node, to display the list of available namespaces.
trans-unit.target: In the left navigation pane, click the Service Bus node, to display the list of available namespaces.

trans-unit.source: Double click the name of the namespace you just created from the list shown.
trans-unit.target: Double click the name of the namespace you just created from the list shown.

trans-unit.source: Click the Configure tab at the top of the page.
trans-unit.target: Click the Configure tab at the top of the page.

trans-unit.source: When a Service Bus namespace is provisioned, a SharedAccessAuthorizationRule, with KeyName set to RootManageSharedAccessKey, is created by default.
trans-unit.target: When a Service Bus namespace is provisioned, a SharedAccessAuthorizationRule, with KeyName set to RootManageSharedAccessKey, is created by default.

trans-unit.source: This page displays that key, as well as the primary and secondary keys for the default rule.
trans-unit.target: This page displays that key, as well as the primary and secondary keys for the default rule.

trans-unit.source: The Service Bus NuGet package is the easiest way to get the Service Bus API and to configure your application with all of the Service Bus dependencies.
trans-unit.target: The Service Bus NuGet package is the easiest way to get the Service Bus API and to configure your application with all of the Service Bus dependencies.

trans-unit.source: The NuGet Visual Studio extension makes it easy to install and update libraries and tools in Visual Studio and Visual Studio Express.
trans-unit.target: The NuGet Visual Studio extension makes it easy to install and update libraries and tools in Visual Studio and Visual Studio Express.

trans-unit.source: The Service Bus NuGet package is the easiest way to get the Service Bus API and to configure your application with all of the Service Bus dependencies.
trans-unit.target: The Service Bus NuGet package is the easiest way to get the Service Bus API and to configure your application with all of the Service Bus dependencies.

trans-unit.source: To install the NuGet package in your application, do the following:
trans-unit.target: To install the NuGet package in your application, do the following:

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click References, then click Manage NuGet Packages.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click References, then click Manage NuGet Packages.

trans-unit.source: Search for "Service Bus" and select the Microsoft Azure Service Bus item.
trans-unit.target: Search for "Service Bus" and select the Microsoft Azure Service Bus item.

trans-unit.source: Click Install to complete the installation, then close the following dialog box.
trans-unit.target: Click Install to complete the installation, then close the following dialog box.

trans-unit.source: To expose an existing WCF SOAP web service for external consumption, you must make changes to the service bindings and addresses.
trans-unit.target: To expose an existing WCF SOAP web service for external consumption, you must make changes to the service bindings and addresses.

trans-unit.source: This may require changes to your configuration file or it could require code changes, depending on how you have set up and configured your WCF services.
trans-unit.target: This may require changes to your configuration file or it could require code changes, depending on how you have set up and configured your WCF services.

trans-unit.source: Note that WCF allows you to have multiple network endpoints over the same service, so you can retain the existing internal endpoints while adding Service Bus endpoints for external access at the same time.
trans-unit.target: Note that WCF allows you to have multiple network endpoints over the same service, so you can retain the existing internal endpoints while adding Service Bus endpoints for external access at the same time.

trans-unit.source: In this task, you will build a simple WCF service and add a Service Bus listener to it.
trans-unit.target: In this task, you will build a simple WCF service and add a Service Bus listener to it.

trans-unit.source: This exercise assumes some familiarity with Visual Studio, and therefore does not walk through all the details of creating a project.
trans-unit.target: This exercise assumes some familiarity with Visual Studio, and therefore does not walk through all the details of creating a project.

trans-unit.source: Instead, it focuses on the code.
trans-unit.target: Instead, it focuses on the code.

trans-unit.source: Before starting the steps below, complete the following procedure to set up your environment:
trans-unit.target: Before starting the steps below, complete the following procedure to set up your environment:

trans-unit.source: Within Visual Studio, create a console application that contains two projects, "Client" and "Service", within the solution.
trans-unit.target: Within Visual Studio, create a console application that contains two projects, "Client" and "Service", within the solution.

trans-unit.source: Add the Microsoft Azure Service Bus NuGet package to both projects.
trans-unit.target: Add the Microsoft Azure Service Bus NuGet package to both projects.

trans-unit.source: This adds all of the necessary assembly references to your projects.
trans-unit.target: This adds all of the necessary assembly references to your projects.

trans-unit.source: First, create the service itself.
trans-unit.target: First, create the service itself.

trans-unit.source: Any WCF service consists of at least three distinct parts:
trans-unit.target: Any WCF service consists of at least three distinct parts:

trans-unit.source: Definition of a contract that describes what messages are exchanged and what operations are to be invoked.
trans-unit.target: Definition of a contract that describes what messages are exchanged and what operations are to be invoked.

trans-unit.source: Implementation of said contract.
trans-unit.target: Implementation of said contract.

trans-unit.source: Host that hosts the WCF service and exposes a number of endpoints.
trans-unit.target: Host that hosts the WCF service and exposes a number of endpoints.

trans-unit.source: The code examples in this section address each of these components.
trans-unit.target: The code examples in this section address each of these components.

trans-unit.source: The contract defines a single operation, AddNumbers, that adds two numbers and returns the result.
trans-unit.target: The contract defines a single operation, AddNumbers, that adds two numbers and returns the result.

trans-unit.source: The IProblemSolverChannel interface enables the client to more easily manage the proxy lifetime.
trans-unit.target: The IProblemSolverChannel interface enables the client to more easily manage the proxy lifetime.

trans-unit.source: Creating such an interface is considered a best practice.
trans-unit.target: Creating such an interface is considered a best practice.

trans-unit.source: It's a good idea to put this contract definition into a separate file so that you can reference that file from both your "Client" and "Service" projects, but you can also copy the code into both projects.
trans-unit.target: It's a good idea to put this contract definition into a separate file so that you can reference that file from both your "Client" and "Service" projects, but you can also copy the code into both projects.

trans-unit.source: With the contract in place, the implementation is trivial.
trans-unit.target: With the contract in place, the implementation is trivial.

trans-unit.source: With the contract and implementation in place, you can now host the service.
trans-unit.target: With the contract and implementation in place, you can now host the service.

trans-unit.source: Hosting occurs inside a <linkText>System.ServiceModel.ServiceHost</linkText><title></title> object, which takes care of managing instances of the service and hosts the endpoints that listen for messages.
trans-unit.target: Hosting occurs inside a <linkText>System.ServiceModel.ServiceHost</linkText><title></title> object, which takes care of managing instances of the service and hosts the endpoints that listen for messages.

trans-unit.source: The following code configures the service with both a regular local endpoint and a Service Bus endpoint to illustrate the appearance, side-by-side, of internal and external endpoints.
trans-unit.target: The following code configures the service with both a regular local endpoint and a Service Bus endpoint to illustrate the appearance, side-by-side, of internal and external endpoints.

trans-unit.source: Replace the string namespace with your namespace name and yourKey with the SAS key that you obtained in the previous setup step.
trans-unit.target: Replace the string namespace with your namespace name and yourKey with the SAS key that you obtained in the previous setup step.

trans-unit.source: In the example, you create two endpoints that are on the same contract implementation.
trans-unit.target: In the example, you create two endpoints that are on the same contract implementation.

trans-unit.source: One is local and one is projected through Service Bus.
trans-unit.target: One is local and one is projected through Service Bus.

trans-unit.source: The key differences between them are the bindings; [NetTcpBinding](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/system.servicemodel.nettcpbinding.aspx) for the local one and NetTcpRelayBinding for the Service Bus endpoint and the addresses.
trans-unit.target: The key differences between them are the bindings; [NetTcpBinding](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/system.servicemodel.nettcpbinding.aspx) for the local one and NetTcpRelayBinding for the Service Bus endpoint and the addresses.

trans-unit.source: The local endpoint has a local network address with a distinct port.
trans-unit.target: The local endpoint has a local network address with a distinct port.

trans-unit.source: The Service Bus endpoint has an endpoint address composed of the string "sb", your namespace name, and the path "solver".
trans-unit.target: The Service Bus endpoint has an endpoint address composed of the string "sb", your namespace name, and the path "solver".

trans-unit.source: This results in the URI "sb://[serviceNamespace].servicebus.windows.net/solver", identifying the service endpoint as a Service Bus TCP endpoint with a fully qualified external DNS name.
trans-unit.target: This results in the URI "sb://[serviceNamespace].servicebus.windows.net/solver", identifying the service endpoint as a Service Bus TCP endpoint with a fully qualified external DNS name.

trans-unit.source: If you place the code replacing the placeholders as explained above into the Main function of the "Service" application, you will have a functional service.
trans-unit.target: If you place the code replacing the placeholders as explained above into the Main function of the "Service" application, you will have a functional service.

trans-unit.source: If you want your service to listen exclusively on Service Bus, remove the local endpoint declaration.
trans-unit.target: If you want your service to listen exclusively on Service Bus, remove the local endpoint declaration.

trans-unit.source: You can also configure the host using the App.config file.
trans-unit.target: You can also configure the host using the App.config file.

trans-unit.source: The service hosting code in this case appears in the next example.
trans-unit.target: The service hosting code in this case appears in the next example.

trans-unit.source: The endpoint definitions move into the App.config file.
trans-unit.target: The endpoint definitions move into the App.config file.

trans-unit.source: Note that the NuGet package has already added a range of definitions to the App.config file, which are the required configuration extensions for Service Bus.
trans-unit.target: Note that the NuGet package has already added a range of definitions to the App.config file, which are the required configuration extensions for Service Bus.

trans-unit.source: The following code example, which is the exact equivalent of the previous code example, should appear directly beneath the system.serviceModel element.
trans-unit.target: The following code example, which is the exact equivalent of the previous code example, should appear directly beneath the system.serviceModel element.

trans-unit.source: This code example assumes that your project C\# namespace is named "Service".
trans-unit.target: This code example assumes that your project C\# namespace is named "Service".

trans-unit.source: Replace the placeholders with your Service Bus service namespace and SAS key.
trans-unit.target: Replace the placeholders with your Service Bus service namespace and SAS key.

trans-unit.source: After you make these changes, the service starts as it did before, but with two live endpoints: one local and one listening in the cloud.
trans-unit.target: After you make these changes, the service starts as it did before, but with two live endpoints: one local and one listening in the cloud.

trans-unit.source: To consume the service, you can construct a WCF client using a [ChannelFactory](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/system.servicemodel.channelfactory.aspx) object.
trans-unit.target: To consume the service, you can construct a WCF client using a [ChannelFactory](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/system.servicemodel.channelfactory.aspx) object.

trans-unit.source: Service Bus uses a token-based security model implemented using SAS.
trans-unit.target: Service Bus uses a token-based security model implemented using SAS.

trans-unit.source: The TokenProvider class represents a security token provider with built-in factory methods that return some well-known token providers.
trans-unit.target: The TokenProvider class represents a security token provider with built-in factory methods that return some well-known token providers.

trans-unit.source: The example below uses the [CreateSharedAccessSignatureTokenProvider](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/microsoft.servicebus.tokenprovider.createsharedaccesssignaturetokenprovider.aspx) method to handle the acquisition of the appropriate SAS token.
trans-unit.target: The example below uses the [CreateSharedAccessSignatureTokenProvider](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/microsoft.servicebus.tokenprovider.createsharedaccesssignaturetokenprovider.aspx) method to handle the acquisition of the appropriate SAS token.

trans-unit.source: The name and key are those obtained from the portal as described in the previous section.
trans-unit.target: The name and key are those obtained from the portal as described in the previous section.

trans-unit.source: First, reference or copy the IProblemSolver contract code from the service into your client project.
trans-unit.target: First, reference or copy the IProblemSolver contract code from the service into your client project.

trans-unit.source: Then, replace the code in the Main method of the client, again replacing the placeholder text with your Service Bus namespace and SAS key.
trans-unit.target: Then, replace the code in the Main method of the client, again replacing the placeholder text with your Service Bus namespace and SAS key.

trans-unit.source: You can now build the client and the service, run them (run the service first), and the client will call the service and print "9."
trans-unit.target: You can now build the client and the service, run them (run the service first), and the client will call the service and print "9."

trans-unit.source: You can run the client and server on different machines, even across networks, and the communication will still work.
trans-unit.target: You can run the client and server on different machines, even across networks, and the communication will still work.

trans-unit.source: The client code can also run in the cloud or locally.
trans-unit.target: The client code can also run in the cloud or locally.

trans-unit.target: The following code shows how to configure the client using the App.config file.

trans-unit.source: The endpoint definitions move into the App.config file.
trans-unit.target: The endpoint definitions move into the App.config file.

trans-unit.target: The following code example, which is the same as the code listed previously, should appear directly beneath the system.serviceModel element.

trans-unit.target: Now that you've learned the basics of the Service Bus relay service, follow these links to learn more.
